cons:
3. People quality. The rapid growth of ecommerce has resulted in need for rapid hiring/promotion. Speed is prioritized at the expense of quality. Many employees lack relevant functional or management expertise required for their roles/responsibilities. Leads to poorly designed and executed projects. Can be a frustrating experience. You have to be an independent thinker to navigate around limited competency. 

4. Professional development. Superficial process and inadequate transparency during performance reviews. Promotions (or lack of it) can be unsubstantiated. Decision-makers susceptible to confirmation bias - grasping at straws to justify decisions. Exacerbates the lack of functional/management expertise in the company. If objectivity is essential to you, this may not be a company of good fit.

5. Culture. Inconsistency in words and actions. For instance, one advocates accountability, yet avoids any for themselves. Or claims to offer autonomy, yet adopts an authoritarian approach. Will depend on the importance of culture to you or your tolerance towards such.

pros:

What I find very upsetting is that majority of company problems come from its own leadership, not competition. I have never seen or imagined that so many high level profiles getting fired or booted, and not just during restructuring, it has been like from the beginning. And all of that for a reason. Company was founded from the foreign capital and nobody from leadership cared about making right decisions, they only cared about their own well being.

It really feels like internal conflict is the biggest obstruction on the way of success.

Also it is hard  to give a fair judgement for all 4 years, as some years were very bad and some were good. I would give 3 starts, because right now company has new leadership, with old leaders are moving away. Let's hope this will be a positive change.

Freedom to do a good job or a "bad job"
Freedom from your line manager, because he doesn’t care if you do good or bad.
Access to metrics and data you need to develop yourself into professional.
You can meet talented experts and occasionally amazing managers.
cons:
Politics surround you from the first day: local versus regional, sales versus operations versus, us versus them.
Nobody cares about your achievements: if you expect to be recognized or promoted, well you will never get any recognition and to get promotion you have to be reporting to an experienced manager in the first place.
Working day and night: it is not just overtimes, it is work on the weekends too.
Keep your passion in check: I have never seen so many people burn out anywhere else.
Do not rely on trust: you can get fired by your manager, just because he or she doesn’t like you.

review_title: Life Below the Powerhouse as Local Software Engineer
pros:
You have the flexibility to do exploration and build your own product as you may have the capability to access the stack to the tech giant even though sometimes it may be limited due to several constraint and especially the scale. You will have the right to analyze, offer, and implement your best solution here which sometimes the simplest solution can lead to big contribution to company and it's exciting.

If you're interested in something, there will be a proper private learning class which you can take and do self development which is super useful, as you can actually learn anything in there from engineering, product, even the non-engineering part is accessible there. 

Most of the time it will be like a startup level bootstrapping as you will have so many discussions and understand the business flow and background properly which makes you not only as an engineer, but also the business / product owner.

You have good allowance for transportation and phone bill which vary on each position / levels and also you have quite good work life balance (unless you will need to have a shift or overtime during events, you may get leave benefit though)
cons:
At certain point, your skill level will not be a caliber of higher level engineer as the main technological stack is already in place from the parent company / regional and not accessible unless it's related to you. Most of the time you will be a lone wolf as the team is too lean or maybe lackluster which if you don't have the initiative and commitment to grow, you will just be another person that will be easily replaceable and a contributor to the high number of the turnover. There is no such thing as nurturing and pair programming / review, and other beautiful things as you hope in engineering. Do your own stuff, grow yourself, ask someone, find something on the documentation (even though most of them might not be readable, you can use google translate on the documentation page hoping that it's understandable). Some people are helpful, some might just want to do their own business. 

Everyone has their own pride, there will be a case that you build a redundant product instead of working together to achieve something causing the lost of resource of manpower and other imaginable bad things in this case. 

There will be some days that you won't be an engineer, but more like an operation based worker which needs to help low level issue but very long process need to be passed which usually some of the process are actually a pass through process which is quite useless. (if you want to grow as a real software engineer, go apply to regional in Vietnam instead of on local level venture)

Sometimes you will be dragged to some random meeting which has no point and clarity because on venture level and you will be facing so many operation or business minded people instead of tech based people which you might get lost on what you want to build due to some drives from the business. Meaning if you don't do something visible to operation based, you can be regarded as no contribution.

Meeting may happen / most likely to happen right after office hour because there might be too much job for the upper level management which impacting the lower level position from senior -> mid -> junior level might need to follow the higher ups.

It might just be a matter 
of time that the local tech team will be disbanded and absorbed somewhere else.
